text: ah hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new clipping
record clipping is a West Coast hip hop
trio this is their sophomore full-length
LP I broke down their debut album mid
city last year it ended up being one of
my favorite hip hop albums of 2013
clipping features the artistic input of
Jonathan Snipes
William Hudson and Davi Diggs all of
whom separately had their own different
musical styles and projects some of
which were collaborative and dabbled in
ambient music Noise music drone hip hop
but in clipping they have found common
ground for all of these musical styles
producing hip hop instrumentals that are
harsh abrasive and loaded with unusual
samples but lyrically clipping came off
as being incredibly influenced by the
violence and the hedonism in gangsta rap
dahveed's lyrics simultaneously showed a
high level of self-awareness like he
wasn't really wholly embracing or
endorsing this lifestyle more just going
for a gritty portrayal of it in his
rhymes and in his delivery I think Dobby
comes through with a high amount of
personality sometimes the speed at which
he raps is really impressive and
together with Jonathan William he can
pull together songs that are either
incredibly catchy like bout that or on
the flip side something much more
cerebral and vivid in terms of
storytelling like the song story after
the release of mid-city it didn't take
clipping too long to sign with Sub Pop
Records and now I'm just kind of sitting
here waiting to see if they can recreate
that noise hop magic
that they were able to on their debut LP
and I I think they do clipping brings
new sounds and experiments to the table
and simultaneously makes a record that I
think is a little deeper a little more
accessible like with the song work work
lead single from this LP and features
all these bouncy metallic samples that
are just springing throughout the
entirety of this track it's a really odd
sound for a hip hop song but
simultaneously I think the song features
one of the darker and more catchy bass
lines on this entire LP a really nice
head bobbing groove this track
instrumentally to me is this catchy as
any new beat from DJ mustard and
obviously pulls a bit of in
fluence from the whole Atlanta snap
revival trend going on right now
then there's tracks on here like
dominoes which very bravely works in a
children's chorus sample and a really
nice piano line it's a risk that pays
off big time especially with an
interesting verse on this track that
features what seems like a vivid lyrical
portrayal of a schoolyard or throw down
then there's the track get up on this
thing which features an amazingly
creative ingenious sample of an alarm
clock going off really not only taking
the sound of the alarm clock but also
borrowing the tempo of the alarm clock
for the background of the verse and
sounds really simple really skeletal of
course you're not hearing anything else
other than this alarm clock but as it
works into the course you get this
amazingly sung hook from Mariel Checotah
and underneath her voice this alarm
clock gets harmonized with other alarm
clock sounds and all of a sudden becomes
panoramic and wide reverb heavy and epic
and this track is a part of a really
interesting progression in the middle of
this album that starts with the song
tonight then goes into the song dream
and then get up and then the track or
die then there's also the track at the
end of this album titled ends and
there's a really awesome fire you just
explosive fast flowing intro that kicks
off this entire LP it's very clear that
clipping paid close attention to the
flow and the feel of these songs as they
segwayed into one another of all the
catch your tracks on this LP the most
glaring flaw is actually in the song
tonight though which features this
ridiculous auto-tune chorus from Davi
where it's actually the the throat enos
of his singing on this track that makes
his performance sound so kind of silly
there's a weird bee changeup that comes
in the middle of this track too that's
sort of unexpected and gangsta move
three 6 mafia actually features on this
track who was actually my most
anticipated feature of this entire LP
but sadly she didn't end up being my
favorite
not that her verse is terrible or
anything like that I would say overall
none of the features on here absolutely
mind-blowing however in the greater
scheme of this LP what they
bringing to the table just makes sense
juice king tea cocked pistol Cree
gangsta boo a lot of these people are
really seasoned long time underground
vets that even though clipping isn't
making true-blue gangster rap it very
clearly shows that they pay attention
and kind of know their [ __ ] so not only
does that sort of bring a bit of
credibility to these tracks but I think
it also brings balance to what dahveed
is doing lyrically and flow wise as well
which is typically very detailed and
flashy now even though there are catch
of your tracks on this LP there's
another side to this album as well that
gets much more dark demented and
experimental like the song Body and
Blood which essentially brings new
meaning to the phrase industrial hip hop
where you've got these heavy thudding
distorted kick drums that are just doing
the song is loaded with all these sexual
phrases that you would typically hear in
a more popular radio friendly hip hop
song but the track is actually about a
type of black widow seductress woman who
lures men to kill them and disassemble
them brutally
and then there's tracks on here like
inside out which sort of is this funny
tongue-in-cheek nonchalant portrayal of
violence in the streets happening around
everyday life and it sort of points out
the absurdity of how weird it is that
this is sort of becoming an everyday
thing a lot of these street violence
themes are also addressed on a much
catchy or beat on the song summertime
there's the song Story 2 which is the
epic sequel to story off of Mid City
which follows the very dark tale of an
entirely different character who seems
to be getting over a kind of a dark past
where he was a bit of a serial arsonist
but on this track maybe because he tells
somebody in confidence who was very
close to him karma makes sure that he
suffers the same fate that many of his
victims did
then there's the song ends which not
only is toward the end of this LP but
also talks about the ends of stories in
the middles of stories and the ends of
lives it's this track and others on here
too where you get da be diving pretty
deeply into a lyrical theme that he
follows very passionately from the
beginning to the end of a song and I
would actually say conceptuality the
themes that play into each individual
song offer this LP and this LP as
whole is maybe one of this records
biggest selling points and then the
entire LP ends off with Williams mix
which is a bit of an odd noise piece
that takes sounds and samples from all
of the songs previous to it and just
delivers them in this really
overwhelming relentless jumble and it's
pretty appropriate finish overall I love
this thing I'm incredibly impressed with
it and I think these guys top what they
did on mid-city I think this is an
incredibly creative hip-hop album
probably the most creative hip-hop album
I'm gonna hear this year and not only is
this LP incredibly experimental but I
think it's good and it's technical and
it is skilled and shows talent by the
traditional standards that we judge
hip-hop for the most part that is the
one thing that I think clipping does
very well in comparison with all the
other experimental hip-hop artists out
there right now I think it's amazing
that they're able to come through with a
record that is so standard and yet so
unorthodox the instrumentals on this LP
overall are disorienting they're strange
they're perplexing and at times
especially on tracks like dominoes
beautiful moving gorgeous and rich I'm
feeling a decent two strong nine on this
LP transition if you given this record
to listen what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it Anthony Fantana clipping
forever
